<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="25%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutterleft -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutterright -->
    <TD width="73%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=maindata -->
</TR>
<!-- Table Width Row END -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-left: 1px solid #000000; padding-left: 2pt; border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt; border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt; border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-left: 1px solid #000000; padding-left: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top" style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">
    Internal Revenue Code section&#160;409A requires
    &#147;nonqualified deferred compensation plans&#148; to meet
    requirements in order to avoid acceleration of the
    recipient&#146;s federal income taxation of the deferred
    compensation. The Internal Revenue Service issued final
    regulations in April 2007 regarding the application of
    Section&#160;409A, which are generally effective January&#160;1,
    2009. In the meantime, companies are expected to comply in
    &#147;good faith&#148; with the statute, taking note of the
    interim guidance issued by the Internal Revenue Service. The
    Company has amended several of its benefit plans in order for
    them to be exempt from Section&#160;409A, while the Company
    continues to provide benefits through several plans that remain
    subject to Section&#160;409A. The terms of most of these plans
    have been amended to bring them into a best efforts compliance
    with the interim guidance on Section&#160;409A, and the terms of
    all the plans will be amended in 2008, as necessary, to meet the
    requirements of the final regulations.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-left: 1px solid #000000; padding-left: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top" style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>

</TD>
<TD style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">MANAGEMENT
    DEVELOPMENT AND COMPENSATION COMMITTEE REPORT</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Management Development and Compensation Committee of the
    board of directors of Apache Corporation reviewed and discussed
    with Company management the Compensation Discussion and Analysis
    set forth above, and based upon such review and discussion,
    recommended to the board of directors that the Compensation
    Discussion and Analysis be included in this Proxy Statement.
</DIV>

<TD colspan="3" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">

    <BR>

</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">All Other
    Compensation</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Officers participate in two qualified retirement plans. The
    401(k) Savings Plan provides a match up to the first six percent
    of base pay and incentive bonus. The Money Purchase Retirement
    Plan, provides an annual six percent company contribution into
    the same investment choices as the 401(k) plan with the
    exception of Company stock. Additionally, officers can elect to
    participate in the Non-Qualified Retirement Savings Plan to
    defer beyond the limits in the 401(k) plan and continue Company
    contributions which exceed the limits in the qualified plans.
    The investment choices mirror those in the qualified retirement
    plans. The Deferred Delivery Plan allows officers the ability to
    defer income in the form of deferred units from the vesting of
    restricted stock units under the Company&#146;s Executive
    Restricted Stock Plan and 2007 Omnibus Equity Compensation Plan.
    The contributions into both non-qualified plans are reported in
    the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation Table. The Company does
    not maintain a defined benefit plan for U.S.&#160;employees.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Apache provides U.S.&#160;employees with two times their base
    salary under group term life insurance. Executives receive the
    first $50,000 of coverage under the same group term life
    insurance plan, and the remaining amount to bring them up to two
    times salary is provided in the form of whole life insurance
    policies, with the exception of Raymond Plank. In exchange for
    surrendering life insurance coverage, a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">20-year</FONT>
    annuity was purchased for Mr.&#160;Plank that pays $31,500
    annually until April&#160;1, 2008. The Company paid the annual
    annuity fee for 2007 and 2006. Mr.&#160;Plank is reimbursed for
    the taxes payable on the income attributable to the premiums and
    fees for these policies.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    To facilitate efficient business travel and for security
    reasons, the board requires the chairman and the chief executive
    officer to use the Company&#146;s aircraft for both business and
    personal travel. Also during 2007, the chief financial officer
    utilized the Company&#146;s aircraft for both business and
    personal travel. Even though the Company considers these costs a
    necessary business expense rather than a perquisite, in line
    with SEC guidance, the following table includes the amounts
    attributable to the top three officer&#146;s personal aircraft
    usage, including trips for Company-supported charitable
    interests. The methodology for the valuation of non-integral use
    of corporate aircraft for disclosure in the Summary Compensation
    Table, in compliance with SEC guidance, calculates the
    incremental cost to the Company for personal use of the aircraft
    based on the cost of fuel and oil per hour of flight;
    trip-related inspections, repairs and maintenance; crew travel
    expenses; on-board catering; trip-related flight planning
    services; landing, parking, and hanger fees; supplies; passenger
    ground transportation; and other variable costs. Additionally,
    the value of trips attributable to philanthropic interests were
    included, even though they are seen as contributing to the
    goodwill of the Company. In addition, Standard Industry Fare
    Level (&#147;SIFL&#148;) tables, published by the Internal
    Revenue Service, are used to determine the amount of
    compensation income that is imputed to the executive for tax
    purposes for personal use of corporate aircraft. With the
    appropriate approvals, these executive officers are reimbursed
    for the taxes on the income attributable to the use of corporate
    aircraft, as approved by the board of directors, and such
    amounts are included in All Other Compensation shown in the
    Summary Compensation Table.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    39
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company provides the chairman with an apartment, car, and
    driver. Mr.&#160;Plank is reimbursed for the taxes on the income
    attributable to these benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the benefits for which all employees are
    eligible, the Company also covers the cost of a complete
    diagnostic annual physical and pays club dues and the full cost
    of enhanced long term disability coverage for the officers.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company provides various forms of compensation related to
    expatriate assignment that differ according to location and term
    of assignment including: foreign service premium, foreign
    assignment tax equalization, location pay, housing and
    utilities, home leave and travel, goods and services allowance,
    relocation expense, and tax return preparation. These items have
    been broken out separately in the following table under Foreign
    Assignment Allowances to reflect the amounts that pertain to
    Mr.&#160;Crum and Mr.&#160;Eichler. Mr.&#160;Crum was Executive
    Vice President&#160;&#151; North Sea until June 2006 and,
    effective July&#160;1, 2007, he transferred to the Canadian
    region as Executive Vice President, Canada. Mr.&#160;Eichler,
    Executive Vice President&#160;&#151; Egypt, resided in Egypt
    during 2006 and 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following table provides a detailed breakdown of the amounts
    for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 under &#147;All Other
    Compensation&#148; in the Summary Compensation Table:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 9pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="40%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutterleft -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutterright -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=lead -->
    <TD width="5%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutterleft -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutterright -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=lead -->
    <TD width="6%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=body -->
    <TD width="1%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=hang1 -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutterleft -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutterright -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=lead -->

    corporate aircraft of which $10,220 was related to
    Company-supported charitable interests.

    overpayment of tax paid by the Company on Mr.&#160;Crum&#146;s
    behalf to the Canada Revenue Agency in connection with the gain
    on his 2007 stock option exercise. It has been determined that
    this income was not subject to withholding in Canada and,
    therefore, the overpayment will be remitted back to the Company

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<A name='124'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">GRANTS OF
    PLAN BASED AWARDS TABLE</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below provides supplemental information relating to
    the Company&#146;s grants of stock options and restricted stock
    units during fiscal year 2007 to the Named Executive Officers.
    There were no stock appreciation rights (&#147;SARs&#148;)
    granted during the last fiscal year. Also included, in
    compliance with SEC rules on disclosure of executive
    compensation, is information relating to the estimated grant
    date fair value of the grants, based upon principles of the
    Black-Scholes option pricing model. Black-Scholes model utilizes
    numerous arbitrary assumptions about financial variables such as
    interest rates, stock price volatility and future dividend
    yield. Neither the values reflected in the table nor the
    assumptions utilized in arriving at the values should be
    considered indicative of future stock performance.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 9pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">This column reflects the number of
    restricted stock units granted under the terms of the Executive
    Restricted Stock Plan. Such restricted stock units vest ratably
    over four years and no dividends are paid on such units until
    vested. The grant date fair value of these awards is based on a
    closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of
    grant.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(2)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">This column sets forth the number
    of shares of the Company&#146;s common stock subject to options
    granted under the terms of the 2007 Omnibus Equity Compensation
    Plan. The options granted under the terms of the 2007 Omnibus
    Equity Compensation Plan are generally nontransferable and
    become exercisable ratably over four years. The options were
    granted for a term of ten years, subject to earlier termination
    in specific circumstances related to termination of employment,
    and are not intended to qualify as incentive stock options under
    Section&#160;422 of the Internal Revenue Code. The exercise
    price and any withholding tax requirements may be paid by cash
    and/or delivery or attestation of already-owned shares of the
    Company&#146;s common stock.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">The Company&#146;s stock option
    plans, including the 2007 Omnibus Equity Compensation Plan, are
    administered by the Stock Option Plan Committee of Apache&#146;s
    board of directors.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
</TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Options granted under the 2007
    Omnibus Equity Compensation Plan are subject to appropriate
    adjustment in the event of reorganization, stock split, stock
    dividend, combination of shares, merger, consolidation or other
    recapitalization of the Company. If there is a change in control
    of the Company, all outstanding options become automatically
    vested so as to make all such options fully vested and
    exercisable as of the date of such change of control. A change
    in control occurs when a person, partnership or corporation
    acting in concert, or any or all of them, acquires more than
    20&#160;percent of the Company&#146;s outstanding voting
    securities. A change in control shall not occur if, prior to the
    acquisition of more than 20&#160;percent of the Company&#146;s
    voting securities, such persons, partnerships or corporations
    are solicited to do so by the Company&#146;s board of directors.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(3)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Raymond Plank requested that he
    not be granted stock options in May 2007&#160;&#151; see
    discussion under the heading &#147;Long-Term Incentive&#148; in
    the Compensation Discussion and Analysis.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

    following page)</FONT></I>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(4)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">The exercise price is the closing
    price per share of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date
    of grant, as reported on The New York Exchange, Inc. Composite
    Transactions Reporting System.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(5)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">The grant date present value is
    based on the Black-Scholes option pricing model adapted for use
    in calculating the fair value of executive stock options, using
    the following assumptions for the grants made May&#160;2, 2007:
    volatility&#160;&#151; 24.35&#160;percent; risk free rate of
    return&#160;&#151; 4.55&#160;percent; dividend yield&#160;&#151;
    0.81&#160;percent; and expected option life&#160;&#151;
    5.5&#160;years. There were no adjustments made to the model for
    non-transferability or risk of forfeiture. The actual value, if
    any, an executive may realize will depend on the excess of the
    market price over the exercise price on the date the option is
    exercised. There is no assurance the value realized by an
    executive will be at or near the value estimated by the
    Black-Scholes model.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    43

    <TD width="3%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=08 type=lead -->
    <TD width="1%" align="right">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=08 type=body -->
    <TD width="3%" align="left">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=08 type=hang1 -->

<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom" style="border-left: 1px solid #000000; padding-left: 2pt">
    <B>&#160;Name(a)</B>
</TD>
<TD style="border-right: 1px solid #000000; padding-right: 2pt">

<TD>
&nbsp;

<TD colspan="3" nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>(#)(b)</B>
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>

    vested under the terms of the Executive Restricted Stock Plan
    and conditional grants vested under the 2005&#160;Share
    Appreciation Plan.
    </FONT></TD>

<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(ii)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Includes compensation of
    $4,096,883 related to the vesting of the fourth periodic
    installment of 61,598&#160;shares under Mr.&#160;Farris&#146;
    conditional stock award, of which 36,959&#160;shares
    (60&#160;percent) were paid to Mr.&#160;Farris in the form of
    stock. The value of the remaining 24,639&#160;shares
    (40&#160;percent) was paid in cash, based on the per share
    closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock of $66.51 on
    December&#160;29, 2006. Required tax withholding on the full
    amount of the fourth vested installment was deducted from the
    portion paid in cash.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 3%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On December&#160;17, 1998, the Company&#146;s board of directors
    granted a conditional stock award to Mr.&#160;Farris for a total
    of 100,000&#160;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock
    (230,992&#160;shares after adjustment for the stock dividends
    and stock split). The award is composed of five periodic
    installments, commencing on January&#160;1st of each of the next
    five years, and vesting on the fifth anniversary following the
    applicable commencement date (subject to acceleration under
    specific circumstances). To receive each installment, which is
    payable 40&#160;percent in cash and 60&#160;percent in stock,
    Mr.&#160;Farris must be employed by the Company on the
    applicable commencement and vesting dates. Mr.&#160;Farris has
    all voting, dividend and liquidation rights for each installment
    of shares as of the applicable commencement date listed below:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 3%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    6,667&#160;shares (15,398&#160;shares after adjustment)
    commencing January&#160;1, 1999, vesting January&#160;1, 2004
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 3%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    13,333&#160;shares (30,798&#160;shares after adjustment)
    commencing January&#160;1, 2000, vesting January&#160;1, 2005
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 3%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    20,000&#160;shares (46,200&#160;shares after adjustment)
    commencing January&#160;1, 2001, vesting January&#160;1, 2006
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 3%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    26,667&#160;shares (61,598&#160;shares after adjustment)
    commencing January&#160;1, 2002, vesting January&#160;1, 2007
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 3%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    33,333&#160;shares (76,998&#160;shares after adjustment)
    commencing January&#160;1, 2003, vesting January&#160;1, 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">EMPLOYMENT
    CONTRACTS AND TERMINATION OF<BR>
    EMPLOYMENT AND
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">CHANGE-IN-CONTROL</FONT>
    ARRANGEMENTS</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company has entered into certain agreements and maintains
    certain plans that will require the Company to provide
    compensation to Named Executive Officers in the event of a
    termination of employment or a change in control of the Company.
    The amount of compensation payable to each Named Executive
    Officer in each situation is listed in the following table for
    fiscal year 2007:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Mr.&#160;Raymond Plank serves the
    Company under an employment agreement entered into in December
    1975, amended and restated in December 1990, and amended in
    April 1996. The agreement has an undefined term and is
    terminable at will by the Company&#146;s board of directors.
    Mr.&#160;Plank&#146;s annual compensation under the agreement is
    determined by the board of directors, but may not be less than
    $450,000. If his service as a director and an officer is
    terminated or if he retires, Mr.&#160;Plank will serve as an
    advisor and consultant to the Company for the remainder of his
    life at annual compensation equal to 50&#160;percent of his
    then-current annual compensation and will receive health,
    dental, and vision benefits for himself, his spouse, and his
    eligible dependents during the remainder of his life. Pursuant
    to the agreement and in exchange for surrendering life insurance
    coverage, an annuity was purchased for Mr.&#160;Plank that pays
    $31,500 annually until April&#160;1, 2008. Mr.&#160;Plank has
    agreed not to render service to any of the Company&#146;s
    competitors for the entire period covered by the agreement. Upon
    Mr.&#160;Plank&#146;s death, a total of $750,000 shall be paid
    (a)&#160;to his designee in equal monthly installments over ten
    years, or (b)&#160;if he has made no designation, in a lump sum
    to his estate.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(2)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Mr.&#160;Farris serves the Company
    pursuant to an employment agreement, dated June&#160;6, 1988,
    under which his base salary as of year-end 2007 is $1,450,000.
    The agreement has an undefined term and may be terminated by
    either the Company or Mr.&#160;Farris on 30&#160;days advance
    written notice. If Mr.&#160;Farris&#146; employment is
    terminated without &#147;cause&#148; (as defined in the
    employment agreement), or if he terminates his employment within
    30&#160;days of a reduction in his salary without a
    proportionate reduction in the salaries of all other Company
    executives, Mr.&#160;Farris will receive, for 36&#160;months
    thereafter, (a)&#160;an amount equal to his base salary as it
    existed 60&#160;days prior to termination and
    (b)&#160;50&#160;percent of the maximum amount for which he
    qualified under the Company&#146;s incentive compensation plan,
    calculated on his base compensation as it existed 60&#160;days
    prior to termination. In the event of Mr.&#160;Farris&#146;
    death during the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">36-month</FONT>
    period, the amounts described above shall be paid to his heirs
    or estate in addition to continuing individual dependent
    benefits for 60&#160;days. Mr.&#160;Farris has agreed not to
    render service to any of the Company&#146;s competitors for the
    term of his employment or, unless he is terminated without
    cause, for 36&#160;months thereafter.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(3)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">On December&#160;17, 1998,
    Mr.&#160;Farris was granted a conditional stock award, the basic
    provisions of which are discussed above in the footnotes to the
    Option Exercises and Stock Vested Table and under the heading
    &#147;Long-Term Incentive&#148; in the Compensation Discussion
    and Analysis. Under the terms of the agreement for this award,
    the vesting of the remaining periodic installment is subject to
    acceleration under specific circumstances. Those circumstances
    generally relate to (a)&#160;termination of
    Mr.&#160;Farris&#146; employment other than for cause,
    (b)&#160;his death or total disability, (c)&#160;an individual
    other than Mr.&#160;Raymond Plank or Mr.&#160;Farris becoming
    the Company&#146;s chief executive officer, or (d)&#160;merger,
    acquisition or other
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">&#147;change-in-control&#148;</FONT>
    of the Company. The fifth and final vesting occurred on
    January&#160;1, 2008, and these provisions were not triggered.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(4)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">In addition to the foregoing, the
    Company has established an income continuance plan. The plan
    provides that all officers of the Company, including the Named
    Executive Officers, and all employees who have either reached
    the age of 40, served the Company for more than ten years, or
    have been designated for participation based upon special skills
    or experience, will receive monthly payments approximating their
    monthly income and continued health and life benefits from the
    Company for up to two years, if their employment is terminated
    as a result of a &#147;change in control&#148; of the Company
    (as defined in the plan).
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 3pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">(5)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 10pt">Although there are no written or
    unwritten contracts, agreements, plans, arrangements, or
    obligations in place for termination without cause, the Company
    has, from time to time, paid executive level positions up to two
    times base salary and benefits continuation for two years.
    Decisions by the Company to pay termination benefits, and in
    what amounts, are determined on an individual case basis and not
    as a matter of policy.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Payments
    Made Upon Death or Disability</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In the event of death for Mr.&#160;Farris, Mr.&#160;Roger Plank,
    Mr.&#160;Crum, or Mr.&#160;Eichler, in addition to the benefits
    listed above in that category, payments will also be made under
    the Company&#146;s life insurance plan and, in the event of
    disability, these executive officers would benefit under the
    company&#146;s disability insurance plan.
</DIV>

<A name='129'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">COMPENSATION
    COMMITTEE INTERLOCKS<BR>
    AND INSIDER PARTICIPATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Frederick M. Bohen, John A. Kocur, A. D. Frazier,&#160;Jr. and
    George D. Lawrence served on the Management Development and
    Compensation (&#147;MD&#038;C&#148;) Committee of the
    Company&#146;s board of directors for all of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Mr.&#160;Kocur, a member of the MD&#038;C Committee since
    September 1991 and a director of the Company since 1977, retired
    as an executive officer in June 1991. Pursuant to the terms of
    an employment agreement in place at the time of his retirement,
    Mr.&#160;Kocur receives health, dental and vision benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Mr.&#160;Lawrence, a member of the MD&#038;C Committee since May
    1997, is the former president and chief executive officer of The
    Phoenix Resource Companies, Inc. (&#147;Phoenix&#148;).
    Mr.&#160;Lawrence joined the Company&#146;s board of directors
    in May 1996, in conjunction with the Company&#146;s acquisition
    of Phoenix by a merger on May&#160;20, 1996, through which
    Phoenix became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Apache. Pursuant to
    the terms of his employment agreement with Phoenix,
    Mr.&#160;Lawrence received medical and dental benefits through
    December 1997. Since that time, he has purchased medical and
    dental coverage through the Company at full cost.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    49
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<A name='130'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">CERTAIN
    BUSINESS RELATIONSHIPS AND TRANSACTIONS</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s board of directors has adopted a code of
    business conduct, which prohibits conflicts of interest between
    a director, officer or employee and the Company. The code
    requires directors, officers and employees to inform the Company
    of any transaction that involves related parties and that may
    give rise to a conflict of interest. Pursuant to its charter,
    the CG&#038;N Committee reviews related party transactions on an
    ongoing basis to prevent conflicts of interest. The CG&#038;N
    Committee reviews a transaction in light of the affiliations of
    the director, officer or employee and the affiliations of such
    person&#146;s immediate family. Transactions are presented to
    the CG&#038;N Committee for approval before they are entered
    into or, if this is not possible, for ratification after the
    transaction has occurred. If the CG&#038;N Committee finds that
    a conflict of interest exists, then it will determine the
    appropriate remedial action, if any. The CG&#038;N Committee
    approves or ratifies a transaction if it determines that the
    transaction is consistent with the best interests of the
    Company. The determination of the CG&#038;N Committee is
    documented in the committee&#146;s minutes. The board of
    directors reviews transactions to determine whether a
    transaction impairs the independence of a director and such
    determination is documented in the board&#146;s minutes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Oil and
    Gas Activities</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    F.&#160;H. Merelli, a member of Apache&#146;s board of
    directors, is chairman of the board, chief executive officer and
    president of Cimarex Energy Co. (&#147;Cimarex&#148;). In the
    ordinary course of business, Cimarex paid to Apache during 2007
    approximately $11,265,000 for Cimarex&#146;s proportionate share
    of drilling and workover costs, mineral interests, and routine
    expenses relating to oil and gas wells in which Cimarex owns
    interests and of which Apache is the operator. Cimarex was paid
    approximately $5,306,000 directly by Apache or related entities
    for its proportionate share of revenues from wells in which
    Cimarex owns an interest and of which Apache is the operator.
    Apache paid to Cimarex approximately $997,000 during 2007 for
    Apache&#146;s proportionate share of drilling and workover
    costs, mineral interests, and routine expenses relating to oil
    and gas wells in which Apache owns interests and Cimarex is the
    operator. Apache was paid approximately $2,789,000 directly by
    Cimarex for its proportionate share of revenues from wells in
    which Apache owns an interest and of which Cimarex is operator.
    These transactions were not material to Apache or Cimarex.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Philanthropic
    Activities</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Since the Company was established in 1954, Apache and its
    employees have been committed to giving back to their
    communities, with special emphasis in three areas&#160;&#151;
    education, the arts, and the environment. To fulfill this
    commitment, Apache initiated three independent
    non-profits&#160;&#151; Springboard&#160;&#151; Educating the
    Future, which funds and builds schools for girls in Egypt&#146;s
    rural villages; The Fund for Teachers, which provides grants to
    fund professional development for pre-kindergarten through high
    school teachers; and Ucross Foundation, which provides artists
    with opportunities to pursue their creative work in a unique
    Wyoming setting, and engages in conservation and holistic
    ranching programs. In addition, Apache Foundation, a charitable
    subsidiary of Apache, is delivering on Apache&#146;s
    environmental commitment by supporting tree plantings and other
    nature-friendly initiatives&#160;&#151; including operation of
    Ucross Foundation&#146;s conservation and ranching programs -
    and other charitable causes.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2007, Apache and its subsidiaries made donations of
    $174,000 in cash, property and services to
    Springboard&#160;&#151; Educating the Future
    (&#147;Springboard&#148;), a U.S.&#160;based non-profit
    organization initiated by Apache. With financial and operational
    support from Apache, its employees, officers, and directors;
    generous individuals; and other corporations, Springboard has
    funded and constructed 200
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    50
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    schools for Egyptian girls who have limited educational
    opportunities in the rural villages where they reside. Apache
    launched this effort as a part of its commitment to improving
    living standards in Egypt, one of the Company&#146;s core
    operating regions. At the request of Apache, George D. Lawrence,
    a director of Apache, serves as the non-paid, non-executive
    chairman of the board of Springboard, and Rodney J. Eichler, an
    executive vice president of the Company, serves as the non-paid
    president and a director of Springboard.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Apache and several of its officers and directors established the
    Ucross Foundation in 1981 as a non-profit organization whose
    primary objectives include the preservation of historic
    buildings, pursuit of holistic ranching practices and
    conservation, and the maintenance of an
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">artists-in-residence</FONT>
    program for writers and other artists. Since that time, the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">artists-in-residence</FONT>
    program has provided a venue for more than 1,300 artists,
    writers, and composers, including winners of the Pulitzer Prize,
    the Tony Award, the National Book Award in poetry, and the
    Whiting Writing Awards. In 2005, the Ucross Foundation decided
    to focus its energies and financial resources on the
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">artists-in-residence</FONT>
    program. Apache Foundation agreed to operate the Ucross
    Foundation&#146;s conservation and holistic ranching programs
    and, in December 2005, entered into a
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">30-year</FONT>
    lease with Ucross Foundation, for the use of Ucross
    Foundation&#146;s ranch property. The annual consideration for
    the lease is $110,000, indexed for inflation, plus payment of
    certain other expenses related to the ranch property. Apache and
    its subsidiaries made donations of $21,000, in cash, property
    and services, to Ucross Foundation in 2007, and paid an
    additional $716 for food, lodging, and other expenses incurred
    for executive and board meetings held at Ucross
    Foundation&#146;s facilities. An Apache subsidiary also paid
    $35,000 to Ucross Foundation during 2007 for the lease of land
    and other services. To help ensure the continuity of Ucross
    Foundation and its charitable purposes, in February 2004,
    Apache&#146;s board of directors approved a conditional
    charitable contribution of $10&#160;million to be made to Ucross
    Foundation in the event of a change of control of Apache, as
    defined in its income continuance plan. During 2007, George D.
    Lawrence, a director of Apache, also served as the non-paid,
    non-executive chairman of the board of trustees of Ucross
    Foundation. Raymond Plank, chairman of Apache&#146;s board of
    directors, G. Steven Farris, a director and officer of Apache,
    and Roger B. Plank, an officer of Apache, are each non-paid
    trustees of Ucross Foundation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2007, Apache and its subsidiaries made donations of
    $1,481,000 in cash, property, and services, to The Fund for
    Teachers: A Foundation to Recognize, Stimulate and Enhance
    (&#147;Fund for Teachers&#148;), a Texas non-profit corporation.
    Fund for Teachers seeks to provide resources directly to
    teachers to support learning experiences of their own design to
    increase their effectiveness with students. At the request of
    Apache, Frederick M. Bohen, a director of Apache, serves as the
    non-paid, non-executive chairman of the board of Fund for
    Teachers, and Patricia Albjerg Graham, a director of Apache, is
    a non-paid director of Fund for Teachers. Raymond Plank,
    chairman of Apache&#146;s board of directors, is the founder and
    a director of Fund for Teachers. G. Steven Farris, a director
    and officer of Apache, is a director of Fund for Teachers.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    From time to time, Apache and its subsidiaries retain Piney
    Creek Construction, an established firm in Buffalo, Wyoming, for
    management of construction projects undertaken by Apache
    subsidiaries. During 2007, Apache and its subsidiaries,
    including Apache Foundation, paid $107,000 to Piney Creek
    Construction for the management of construction projects in
    Wyoming. Piney Creek Construction is owned by Michael R. Plank,
    son of Raymond Plank, chairman of Apache&#146;s board of
    directors, and brother of Roger B. Plank, an officer of Apache.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    51
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<A name='131'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">CONSIDERATION
    OF STOCKHOLDER PROPOSAL</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The proponent of the following stockholder proposal has stated
    that they intend to present such proposal at the annual meeting.
    In accordance with federal securities regulations, we have
    included the stockholder proposal and supporting statement
    exactly as submitted by the proponent. The Company is not
    responsible for the content of the stockholder proposal or the
    supporting statement. The board of directors has recommended a
    vote <B>AGAINST </B>the proposal for the reasons set forth below.
</DIV>
<A name='132'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Proposal&#160;&#151;
    Reimbursement of Proxy Expenses (Item&#160;No.&#160;5 on Proxy
    Card)</FONT></I>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The following proposal has been resubmitted by the American
    Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees
    (&#147;AFSCME&#148; or the &#147;Union&#148;) on behalf of the
    AFSCME Employee Pension Plan. The proponent states that it holds
    2,174&#160;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock
    (0.00065&#160;percent of the shares issued and outstanding as of
    February&#160;29, 2008). The proponent&#146;s address is
    1625&#160;L&#160;Street, N.W., Washington,&#160;D.C.
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">20036-5687.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;RESOLVED, that pursuant to section&#160;109 of the
    Delaware General Corporation Law and Article&#160;XIII
    section&#160;1 of the bylaws of Apache Corporation
    (&#147;Apache&#148;), stockholders of Apache hereby amend the
    bylaws to add the following Section&#160;22 to
    Article&#160;V.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;The board of directors shall cause the corporation to
    reimburse a stockholder or group of stockholders (together, the
    &#147;Nominator&#148;) for reasonable expenses
    (&#147;Expenses&#148;) incurred in connection with nominating
    one or more candidates in a contested election of directors to
    the corporation&#146;s board of directors, including, without
    limitation, printing, mailing, legal, solicitation, travel,
    advertising and public relations expenses, so long as
    (a)&#160;the election of fewer than 50% of the directors to be
    elected is contested in the election, (b)&#160;one or more
    candidates nominated by the Nominator are elected to the
    corporation&#146;s board of directors, (c)&#160;stockholders are
    not permitted to cumulate their votes for directors, and
    (d)&#160;the election occurred, and the Expenses were incurred,
    after this bylaw&#146;s adoption. The amount paid to a Nominator
    under this bylaw in respect of a contested election shall not
    exceed the amount expended by the corporation in connection with
    such election.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><U><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">SUPPORTING
    STATEMENT</FONT></U></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;In our opinion, the power of stockholders to elect
    directors is the most important mechanism for ensuring that
    corporations are managed in stockholders&#146; interests. Some
    corporate law scholars posit that this power is supposed to act
    as a safety valve that justifies giving the board substantial
    discretion to manage the corporation&#146;s business and
    affairs.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;The safety valve is ineffective, however, unless there is
    a meaningful threat of director replacement. We do not believe
    such a threat currently exists at most U.S.&#160;public
    companies, including Apache. Harvard Law School professor Lucian
    Bebchuk has estimated that there were only about 80 contested
    elections at U.S.&#160;public companies from 1996 through 2002
    that did not seek to change control of the corporation.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;The unavailability of reimbursement for director election
    campaign expenses for so-called &#147;short
    slates&#148;&#160;&#151; slates of director candidates that
    would not comprise a majority of the board, if
    elected&#160;&#151; contributes to the scarcity of such
    contests. (Because the board approves payment of such expenses,
    as a practical matter they are reimbursed only when a majority
    of directors have been elected in a contest.) The proposed bylaw
    would provide reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in
    successful short slate efforts&#160;&#151; but not contests
    aimed at changing control
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    52
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    by ousting a majority or more of the board&#160;&#151; with
    success defined as the election of at least one member of the
    short slate.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;The bylaw would also cap reimbursable expenses at the
    amount expended by the company on the contested election. We
    believe that the amount spent by a dissident stockholder or
    group will rarely exceed the amount spent by the company, but
    the cap ensures that the availability of reimbursement does not
    create an incentive for wasteful spending.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 4%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    &#147;We urge stockholders to vote for this proposal.&#148;
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>The Company&#146;s board of directors unanimously recommends
    that you vote &#147;AGAINST&#148; this proposal for the
    following reasons:</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    This proposal was made by the same stockholder proponent last
    year and received only 11.3&#160;percent of the vote in favor of
    the proposal. The stated purpose of the proposal is to encourage
    proxy contests by requiring all of our stockholders to bear the
    expense of any one stockholder who seeks to elect candidates of
    its own choosing to the board, permitting campaigns by minority
    stockholders (at no cost to them) to seat special interest
    candidates. The proposal asks the board to adopt a standard for
    reimbursing proxy solicitation expenses that is inconsistent
    with Delaware law and that would cause the Company&#146;s board
    of directors to abdicate its fiduciary responsibility to
    determine whether insurgents should be reimbursed for such
    expenses.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Company&#146;s board of directors is charged with choosing
    director nominees that represent the interests of all
    stockholders, and it chooses candidates who will promote
    long-term stockholder value for all. The board of directors has
    been highly successful in this role, with Apache achieving
    consistent strong growth in operating results. Individual
    stockholders are not bound by the fiduciary duties that require
    directors to nominate director candidates who will serve all of
    our stockholders and pursue Apache&#146;s best interests.
    Individual stockholders may pursue their own personal interests
    and are free to nominate director candidates without regard to
    whether those candidates are committed to the long-term best
    interests of other stockholders. To impose upon Apache the
    obligation to pay for the campaigns of opposition candidates,
    regardless of their fitness or suitability, would not represent
    good governance and would do little to further our business
    strategies.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The board of directors also disagrees with the apparent premise
    underlying the proposal: that proxy contests designed to elect
    representatives of particular constituencies are a good thing
    for the Company, its stockholders, employees, and other
    stakeholders. To the contrary, proxy contests of this type can
    lead to a balkanized board of directors where competing factions
    make it difficult for a company to pursue a successful business
    model. The board of directors believes that the best results for
    stockholders are obtained when directors act together
    constructively and collegially to create stockholder value.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The board of directors is also concerned that encouraging proxy
    contests may deter capable men and women from agreeing to join
    the board. Through the Corporate Governance and Nominating
    Committee, the board of directors considers persons suggested by
    stockholders and others as potential directors. The board of
    directors believes that some attractive director candidates
    would not be interested in standing for election to the board of
    directors if they believe that the nominating process will give
    rise to frequent proxy contests. Hence, adoption of the proposal
    could impair our ability to attract accomplished candidates to
    serve Apache as directors.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    For the reasons set forth above, the board of directors believes
    that the proposal will not serve the best interests of the
    Company and its stockholders.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>THE COMPANY&#146;S BOARD OF DIRECTORS, THEREFORE, UNANIMOUSLY
    RECOMMENDS THAT YOU VOTE &#147;AGAINST&#148; THE UNION&#146;S
    PROPOSAL.</B>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    53
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 91%; margin-left: 4%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<A name='133'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 18pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">INDEPENDENT
    REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Policy
    for Approval of Audit, Audit-Related and Permitted Non-Audit
    Services</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    All audit, audit-related, and tax services were pre-approved by
    the Audit Committee, which concluded that the provision of such
    services by Ernst&#160;&#038; Young LLP was compatible with that
    firm&#146;s independence in the conduct of its auditing
    functions. The Audit Committee&#146;s Audit and Non-Audit
    Services Pre-Approval Policy provides for pre-approval of
    specifically described audit, audit-related, tax services, and
    permissible non-audit services. The policy authorizes the Audit
    Committee to delegate its pre-approval authority to one or more
    of its members.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Auditor
    Fees and Services</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Ernst&#160;&#038; Young was the Company&#146;s independent
    registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year 2007.
    Representatives of Ernst&#160;&#038; Young will be present at
    the annual meeting and will have an opportunity to make a
    statement if they desire to do so and to respond to appropriate
    questions regarding Apache business.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Ernst&#160;&#038; Young&#146;s audit report on Apache&#146;s
    consolidated financial statements as of and for the fiscal year
    ended December&#160;31, 2007 did not contain any adverse opinion
    or disclaimer of opinion, and it was not qualified or modified
    as to uncertainty or audit scope; however, it was modified for
    the adoption of new accounting principles.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During Apache&#146;s most recent fiscal year ended
    December&#160;31, 2007, and through the filing date of this
    proxy statement, there were no disagreements with
    Ernst&#160;&#038; Young on any matter of accounting principles
    or practices, financial statement disclosure, or auditing scope
    or procedure, which disagreements, if not resolved to
    Ernst&#160;&#038; Young&#146;s satisfaction, would have caused
    Ernst&#160;&#038; Young to make reference to the subject matter
    of the disagreement in connection with their report; and there
    were no reportable events, as described in Item&#160;304 (a) (1)
    (v)&#160;of
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Regulation&#160;S-K.</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 12pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    During 2007 and 2006, Ernst&#160;&#038; Young provided various
    services to Apache. The aggregate fees for each of the following
    types of services are set forth below:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
